text.author: Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia
text.title: Évariste Galois
text.summary1: (human1) This excerpt gives details on French mathematician Évariste Galois' final days, in which he wrote his famous mathematical testament in a letter to Auguste Chevalier, before being shot in a duel provoked under unclear and possibly suspicious circumstances, on May 30th, 1832, and dying the next day.
text.summary2: (claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) Évariste Galois, a brilliant young mathematician, spent his final days revising his mathematical theories and publishing independently after a rejection from the Academy, before dying at age 20 in a mysterious duel allegedly involving a romantic entanglement.
text.summary3: (gpt4o; postedited) Évariste Galois, a brilliant mathematician crucial to equation theory, died at 20 in a mysterious duel after his final days, which were marked by political activism and academic rejection, yet he left a lasting mathematical legacy, although his death remains surrounded by speculation.
text.summary4: (Llama-3.2-3B-Instruct) Évariste Galois, a young French mathematician, was fatally wounded in a duel on May 30, 1832, and died the following morning at the age of 20, leaving behind a legacy of mathematical ideas that were later developed by others.
text.summary5: (Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct; postedited) Évariste Galois, a mathematician and revolutionary, spent his last night organizing his mathematical ideas and writing letters due to a disputed duel that resulted in his fatal shooting and subsequent burial in an unknown grave.
